author: BatMeckley
content:
God I love this discord. 
To me 90% of the reason big producers are paying many thousands a day to be in a studio the past 15-20 years is to just not have to worry about shit. Anyone can make a record at home these days; part of being in an “actual” studio is the cocoon of creativity. If the assistant takes more than a couple of minutes to patch anything in, bring up the piano, or recommend the best Thai place in town, they’re blowing it. I had an assistant once at this place famous for making cookies on site, bring me my normal plate of cookies I always ask for and while I was comping I ate half of one, put it back on the plate, and continued working. He didn’t say a word, got up, grabbed the plate, and disappeared for a few minutes and came back. “Hey man, I know you normally house the entire plate of cookies so when you put that one back I checked with the kitchen and last week I guess they changed the cookie recipe, and they’re gonna make em like they used to for you.” 😂😂. I asked for that dude every session after, less for the cookies but more for the insane attention to detail and telepathy. One of max’s engineers started as a Conway assistant, and as good of an engineer as he was he also prepped the best Hookahs and was just a great hang. Max ended up hiring him for his own studio. We’re in a people business, try to be attentive and a good person to have around, for all the reasons that go beyond knowing how to set an attack on an 1176. 

The flip side is, if you’re booking a studio as a producer, the assistants are what really make the studio run. Treat them well. Know their names. Give them credit. No assistant on any session I ever did paid for their own meal, they got what the artist got.  They most of the time got engineer credits. Help them along. As with all things, mutual respect goes a long way.

author: peterlabberton
content: I was lucky to be in a handful of really great, holy grail gear-packed studios as I was *just* learning the ropes. Having the experience of doing a mix in a world-class room and getting to run everything through the Fairchild and the API and the multiple plates and and and… and then listening back the next day and realizing you just created a steaming pile of dogshit is a humbling experience everyone coming up would benefit from!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Fun little chat with my old mic tech in LA. He and his wife sing together and are getting back into it. 

He’s got a vintage 67 and 269 in pristine condition, is mostly doing audio for movies now so he’s stepped out of tech work and will only send his mics to Germany to get worked on. 

That’s all preamble for this part of the story. 

He recently did a shootout on pres & compressors for his home setup. Ended up selling his vintage Neve & La2a in favor of the ORIGINAL MBOX. The first iteration that had Focusrite pres I guess? Had to buy old laptops to run ProTools 8. Has 3 rigs at his place and got ‘em all for under a $100. 

Boys & Girls, Vintage Digital is officially en vogue.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
I’ve referenced this more than once in conversations here and in DMs with various people but it is remarkably applicable to what we do too if you can open up the aperture a little 

Musk’s Engineering Philosophy:

Musk overviewed his five step engineering process, which must be completed in order:

**1) Make the requirements less dumb.** The requirements are definitely dumb; it does not matter who gave them to you. He notes that it’s particularly dangerous if an intelligent person gives you the requirements, as you may not question the requirements enough. “Everyone’s wrong. No matter who you are, everyone is wrong some of the time.” He further notes that “all designs are wrong, it’s just a matter of how wrong.”

**2) Try very hard to delete the part or process.** If parts are not being added back into the design at least 10% of the time, not enough parts are being deleted. Musk noted that the bias tends to be very strongly toward “let’s add this part or process step in case we need it.” Additionally, each required part and process must come from a name, not a department, as a department cannot be asked why a requirement exists, but a person can.

**3) Simplify and optimize the design.** This is step three as the most common error of a smart engineer is to optimize something that should not exist.

**4) Accelerate cycle time.** Musk states “you’re moving too slowly, go faster! But don’t go faster until you’ve worked on the other three things first.”

**5) Automate.** An important part of this is to remove in-process testing after the problems have been diagnosed; if a product is reaching the end of a production line with a high acceptance rate, there is no need for in-process testing.

author: Bonati12461
content: And sorry to bang on about this, but something that is critical to the audio quality on a record that is way out of most pro-audio people’s view is the state of the cutting lathe being used to do the master cut. Many people working in audio have never even seen such a machine. They are complicated - there are techs who work on consoles who won’t touch cutting lathes. IMO the best lathes were made by Neumann in the 70s/early 80s, and that was a long time ago. You have a TON of electronics and mechanics that need to be refurbished / restored to get the lathe to make some great cuts. Some engineers are cutting on some nicely restored systems and some are using some OLD stuff which should have been pulled for maintenance decades ago. Imagine if 50% of the records today were mastered on 50 year old loudspeakers with blown drivers and mismatched crossovers. We might notice.

author: popthetrunk
content: Gordon Moore, co-founder of Intel and observer of Moore’s Law has sadly passed away. Moore cofounded Intel with Robert Noyce, inventor of the first integrated circuit to be commercially produced. They both at one point worked for Fairchild Semiconductor, one of the many companies owned by Sherman Fairchild, which included the Fairchild Recording Equipment Corp. that we know as the designer and oem of the Fairchild 670. https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/newsroom/news/gordon-moore-obituary.html

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Love this discussion. All great points — my gut says there is a distinction between the producer/engineer role here and the artist. The learn grammar, be able to adjust and deliver on a vision/etc all lend themselves to being amazing technically and doing the reps to have those skills. Very useful on the service side

But some artists just have it like that. It’s irrelevant, they just crush stuff and have a vision. Pure talent. And probably the rarest ones have both sides and are aware of it. Then you’re truly dangerous

Have seen this with some football guys I’ve played with — I was one of the ones who studied the game deeply and could improve. But other guys showed up on day one, knew absolutely nothing but could just ball. Their knowledge of the game didn’t even matter, they could just ball on instinct. Of course they worked hard, but there was a different level of talent there. And look at them now, cashing checks in the NFL

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: peterlabberton
content: I typically go for a blumlein or ortf-ish setup as it just sounds more coherent to me. The one thing that I’ll do pretty frequently, and if I’m going for more exaggerated width, is what I think of as the Nigel Godrich technique: one overhead dead center, and two spread real wide basically over the cymbals. If you watch the From The Basement videos, he’s always got a U47/48 in the middle and Coles on the sides. You angle the sides so the opposite side of the kit is in the null. Super wide, and then you have the mono sound from the 47. I love this setup and do it a lot if I have the time/don’t get lazy and just put up an r88 or something and call it a day.

author: cian riordan
content: Nice ribbon (RCA 44 is my typical choice, 4038 can be a little too midrangey) about 3-4 ft off the bridge is usually the bulk of my sound. Pepper in room mics if you’ve got a nice space. Usually a good amount of EQ to pull out the “honk”. The cleanest, quietest preamp is usually the one for strings, especially if the playing is dynamic . I’d often used my Grace pre when a UTA pre wasn’t available. I would avoid inexpensive condenser mics like the plague… ive had better luck with an SM57.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zakhiggins the best producers in the world are great because of this. getting the best out of an artist/ vocalist. your job should be getting the best performance. most young artists change their vibe around a fancy mic in a studio. some of them show up and kill it. your job is to adapt and find that vibe quickly, while being super comfortable. this job is way more psychology and vibe than technical know how!

we recorded the hives vocals on Tik Boom with an SM7 on a straight mic stand in front of Pelle's live wedge monitors. HE knew that's how he could rock out the most and get the best vocal.

eric valentine gave Adam from Taking Back Sunday a neumann hand held condenser on a long cable so he could move around the room and perform.

i just figured out how to edit them after the fact. they weren't as clean as standing in front of a U47 with a pop screen. but they sounded fucking awesome

author: CK
content:
I finally got around to watching the Castelli mixes Kaien Cruz JFTR.  That mix is an incredible lesson in so many ways.  When Castelli convinces them to try and remove the mix bus and let it breathe, it was just amazing.  The whole track came to life. I have spent so much time obsessing over my mix buss, to now just delete everything on there.  No more "safety net".  Time to step up.
I have also been obsessed with the new Kimbra album.  The mixes are INSANE.  And then of course I finally look and see.....Castelli did it.  And now that I understand his current view on letting the dynamics breathe, I get why it has that sound.  At least a major factor as to why.
When they described it as feeling "dangerous", I realized how I often use my Mix Buss to feel "safe".

author: Rollmottle
content: That was my world in the late 90s and 2000s. Buddy ran a house club here and I got to meet Francois, Kerry Chandler, David Mancuso, DJ Harvey and all the torch bearers of Larry Levan's legacy. Going to Body & Soul was life changing...never seen or experienced anything like it since. Pure positivity, energy, community and passion for music and dance.

author: spectrummasters
content:
a great read thanks Anthony, v informative 

Quote :  . “Great dance music is constructed as much from silence as it is from sound; what gets left out is as important as what goes in.” 

......and so the truth was spoken ..

Interesting to me, was the mention of Timmy regisford , as his shelter club being mentioned by interviews with Dennis ferrer was what first caught my ear to the wave of NY house coming out just as uk garage was beginning to tire and split into UK funky, grime and dubstep . I went into UK Funky and we were all listening to Ferrer and Chandler .....Quentin Harris was another great dj with some great tracks at that time .....we had a club in London called the east village which was explicitly mimicking the Manhattan east village vibe at the time and Quentin Harris held a night there monthly I’d go down to .

V v cool. 

He and Dennis personified the concept of using space and silence in a production imho .

Check Dennis ferrer - touched the sky . This tune was huge here . Wonderful house production 

And Quentin Harris remix of Justin timber lake “what goes around “ ....a beguiling steady building deep groove .

The opening  section to sonny fodera and MK,s  “asking “ (out now ) reminded me of proper house and garage from the late 90s / early 00,s like Rui da silva touch me and trippin by gold trix feat Andrea brown 

.....and it had me thinking about doing a few house and garage tracks again myself. The hip hop culture imho has become stagnant and toxic at the mo imho and I don’t perceive much  appreciation for artistry as it stands.....feel myself drifting off into other genres ...

Maybe time to swap the 808 back to the 909

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ehhhh I saw this earlier and it seems dangerous to me for a young artist. Mayer gets to have that perspective because his near sociopathic belief in himself and his ability gave him a couple decades of success to now have the room to try something new.

It’s like a new band going “well Radiohead had succes with ‘in Rainbows’ being released independently on a pay what you want model, we should too!” Without any understanding that a big reason that Radiohead could do that was because they had 5 fantastic records and a fan base built on those that were a product of the major label system before that.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
I feel like that's a bit open ended because different people view the bottleneck in different places, and it depends how many mics you need to record, but I'll take a stab at it:

MBox Studio: $600 (and comes with Pro Tools Studio, helps with flying sessions around even if you aren't a PT main)
Logic Pro: $200
SM7b or AT4040: $300-400
DT770: $170 x2 (record a friend too)
IN8v2 pair: $800
Stands/concrete: $20-100
Cables/mic stands: $50-150
AirPods Pro 2: $200 (obv reasons)

$2790 when adding max values, plus regional tax
more if you add a computer but most people already have one

you can expand inputs with Opto if you want to track a rhythm section

author: LAPhill

For a bit of perspective: One of the top articles on CNN was about an AI generated image of the pope and how we’re headed into dangerous times when we’re flooded by images and can’t tell real from fake. I remember being 10 years old at the barbershop (RIP when I had hair and went to a barber) and reading about this dangerous “Photoshop” technology that would make it hard to tell what was real. 

AI offers incredible breakthroughs, things we can’t fathom, but this ain’t the first time things have been disrupted.

author: David Fuller
content: I come from guitar amp-land, so Pultecs pretty much immediately made sense to me

author: David Fuller
content: The last filter in the Pultec is the LF boost/cut. The low cut has its capacitor bank connected in series to the output; The low boost has them connected in parallel with the output, with the output going to ground. Both are again acting as very broad shelving filters, though with *slightly* different center frequencies - which is why the "pultec LF trick" exists

author: spectrummasters
content: . These scenes later splintered into U.K. funky (where I started producing ) that took New York house producers like Dennis Ferrer and Kerri chandler and gave it a little more bass and percussion ……and then Atlanta trap took over here for a good few years until a few years back until today with the youngers like 808 melo, chencs, ghostie etc creating U.K. drill from Chicago drill which has now gone back to yall in America via pop smoke as Brooklyn drill . Pop smokes hits were written by a kid a few miles down the road from me and mixed by Jess Jackson who comes from our uk garage scene It’s a never ending push to be the freshest and most cutting edge .  To be the future .

author: David Fuller
content: if we just stay in the creative fields, people on film sets work even more hours than most in music, and it can be substantially more dangerous; outside of that, there's... well, tech is pretty unforgiving if we stay with more "white collar" jobs

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, to be clear, different doesn’t always mean worse… according to the smart dudes at chandler the 500 series tg2 is actually closer to the original console, though it is definitely different than the regular tg2.

author: spectrummasters
content: So , I don’t really watch tv or anything just music related or science related docs . So (and I know it catches shade ) MWTM is my Netflix bro . Whether it’s downtime or I have a mix to do …..there’s so many great mixers on there , Shawn Everett , andy Wallace , tchad Blake , etc etc etc ….just hours of conversations I love to listen to about a song and what brought it to completion . Over the last year or two they’ve really stepped up the frequency of new content and the deals they have made with plug in companies and firms like samply and others , it nearly pays for itself to be fair . There’s a lot going for it imo , not least to mention …..it being a good consistent source from people who know their onions . Shawn Everett’s tape / match eq technique ….that jacquire king kick/bass vu meter balance thing , the andy Wallace ambient drum triggers ….schepps and his dual mono 1176 back bus 🚎 ….even al Schmitt in capitol mixing with no eq …..these have all been really inspirational ideas and convos I’ve seen from there . At this point they’ve got so much content on there bro ….and even the JJP don’t send me 48 kHz files convo 😂. What’s not to love

author: spectrummasters
content: ....I’m currently going into  another electrical engineering rabbit hole that’s got me learning the details of the routing of the old SSL 4000 desks (just by online docs and discussion ) and I have to say when it comes to signal flow , those SSL engineers were bloody clever .....With the whole in line thing and matrix and float etc etc .....it makes me realise how much of our daw s mixers and the routing options we have available ......we owe the concepts to the brain waves of electrical engineers in the 70s , they really thought shit through !!! TIP O my hat to the-electrical  engineers

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Random Manley Q,

I only have a few Manley plugins, and none through UAD, and just saw that UAD is having a big sale on them - Are there any Manley Plugins people find themselves consistently reaching for?

I’m interested in the Mic PreAmp, marked down from$130 to $29 rn, anyone have experience with it?

I currently use the UAD Avalon VT-737 as my preamp, but does anyone have experience using multiple preamps in an input chain?

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: If you are not too far from Acton, Massachusetts, there is also very good studio Wondersmith audio. Dan Fox is the proprietor there. He has Neumann 310s with matching subwoofers.  I was just there yesterday, although I’m not sure if his availability.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Did anyone ever remake this plugin? This was the Abbey Road EMI TG12413 2005 compressor/ limiter and it was my favorite dynamics plugin but then they stopped making it for some reason. I think someone made a version after this version was discontinued, but it sounded very different. This was like 10 years ago.

Anyone ever use this and find a substitute? It had such a great sound that had the extreme of a distressor or a devilloc, but it didn't sound choked like both of those do at extreme settings.

cc @cian riordan
